data.name: Character Options
entries: It begins with a subtle question. What are we? Where can we go? What are we meant to be? Those are things many young aspiring practitioners asked, before discovering the only means for an answer: the Art.

The Art of arcane magic has been honed for millenia in Kyrmoria. Ancient civilizations rose and fell, some due to conflicting interests and thirst for power that drove them to infighting, some others due to extraordinary yet devastating experiments.

Nowadays, in times of peace, theologists and scholars of the arcane alike debate constantly over the origin of arcana. Devotees of the divine claim it was a gift bestowed upon mortals by Temporus, the deity of time and magic, while mages support the idea of the mortal claim, the fact that magic was always there, embracing us through the Weave. We just had to understand it in order to manipulate it.

Historically, there have been, as is to be expected, great leaps in the development of the Art in times of war. The Dragon War saw many powerful archmages rise and fall, ultimately culminating with the elven archmage Elbalar sacrificing himself in the Nexus of Time to shift the current timeline and alter reality, successfully, for the time being, avoiding a material and celestial plane wide apocalypse.

It is the writer's conviction, as Elbalar's student, that magic is not panacea. A mage's duty is to influence the world, to pursue truths and knowledge as a tool of understanding. As alluring as the concept of the True Magic is, one should tread carefully and with responsibility regarding their craft's use.

After the Sundering, magic has been.. unstable. Even wizards of the highest caliber exercise patience for Celestial and Material Nexuses alignments, so that they can channel their most powerful spells. Not to mention, the use of conjuration as a means for teleportation and such, has produced many results some would deem interesting, at the very least. The mana, the material from which the threads of the Weave are carefully woven are scarce, and since there is peace, the cycle of replenishment from the Celestial planes has halted.

Where does this leave us? Kyrmorians have practiced magic for ages, honing the Art to such lengths that even mages are able to perform feats only powerful clerics could, in the past. But, with the limitations placed upon us for the last 300 years, the process has been a slow, yet dedicated one. We cannot say what the future holds, but one thing is certain. Masters of Arcana still walk and scry the lands, their arsenal full of powerful tricks and enchantments, racing for the one goal: the one True Magic, and the restoration of the Nexus of Arcana.

This document includes some interesting creations that the writer deems worthy of mention, as well as cataloguing training techniques for the initiated to the Art. To the reader, the writer wishes a good read and extends but a few warnings: do not attempt to impersonate deities, do not attempt teleportation or planar magic without meticulous calculations, and should you come across a Ley Line or a Nexus, do not wish for anything. Seriously.
{@i - Adalberto di Santi-Umeril, Student of Elbalar the Wise, Archmage and Headmaster in the Academy of the Arcane Arts & Militia of Bastion, Sage of the First Light}

entries.name: Eldritch Invocation Options
entries: When you choose eldritch invocations, you have access to these additional options.

entries.name: Class Kits
entries: At your GM's discretion, when you make a character, gain your 1st level in a class or reach a level in a class that grants you the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can take a class kit from those presented in this section. The Class Kits tables for each class describe if the class kit allows you to qualify as a member of that class for anything in the game that requires it. Refer to the "{@variantrule class kits|CoH-CAPG|Class Kit Rules}" section for how class kits work.

For more Class Kits, refer to {@link Complete Divine Player's Guide|https://drive.google.com/file/d/1CZArbysKVKywzMJ-2pdtwtV9wdeTvEOr/view}, Chapter 2, and {@link Complete Rogue|https://drive.google.com/file/d/1vcktsj9kaHadiyID_g2rywx0DZI85gb2/view}.

entries.name: Arcane Magic in Kyrmoria
entries: When the dark god Xyndaran was imprisoned, he scattered pages of his Black Gospel all over the material plane, as a final act of defiance against his fellow deities. And, as is natural, mortal curiosity drove destiny to unfold.

About 6400 years before the Sundering, during what was called the Age of Great Magic, many practitioners of Old Magic, Gramarye, started uncovering pages of the gospel and stuyding its more structured and robust approach towards the manipulation of mana. It was around this time that what would be latter known as "the Art" took a proper form, as well as the division of spellcrafting into schools of magic. Yet, many abused this newfound power, falling to the dark temptations hidden in the gospel's pages. This caused Temporus, the dragon god of magic and time to instruct the dragons of the material plane to teach mortals how to manipulate the Weave ethically, without needing to delve into the profane practices of Xyndaran's residual malice.

At some point during this era, two major factions opposed each other: those who abused the Weave, harnessing the dark magics of the gospel, and the disciplines of the dragons, who sought balance. The rising tensions culminated in an epic clash that saw the dark mages defeated, and the emergences of those taught by the great wyrms as the first archmages of history.

However, there is no such thing as no dark spot in history, and while the archmages were celebrating their victory and preparing the world for a new era, others plotted in the shadows. Thendrix Hollow, one of the first archmages, grew curious and greedy, seeking out the secrets of the Black Gospel. He believed that the dragons presented only one side of the coin, and wished to unravel the greater truths of magic. Students gathered around him, as well as other ambitious figures, creating the faction that would survive history to this very day: the Apostles of the Gospel.

entries.name: The Sundering
entries: At some point after the end of the Dragon Wars, a former hero of the war, now only mentioned in history books as the Dreadlord, rallied a great army. Consuming the Nexus of Arcana, and corrupting the Weave itself, he used his power to force the gods into the material plane. Rare records of this event, known as the Sundering, tell of how the stars in the sky fell and blinked out of existence one after the other, as the Dreadlord waged his vengeful war against he makers of the cosmos, now restrained in physical forms and unable to access their true powers. The Dreadlord was eventually defeated, but the aftermath of his actions left magic broken, wild and unpredictable.

entries.name: Factions of Kyrmoria
entries: Below, we present information on two of the most infamous factions of Kyrmoria: the Apostles of the Gospel, profaned followers of the chained god Xyndaran, and the Cabal, a group of outcast mages running the largest dark market in the continent.

entries.name: Apostles of the Gospel
entries: Little is known about the origin of the apostles. Scarce references spread around Kyrmoria, date the cult's beginning some centuries before the Dragon Wars, in the form of a small sect of worshippers to some cryptic deity. In later times there have been incidents of their appearance circling grand events of theurgy, spread among numerous religious calendars, or in ancient long lost tombs searching maniacally. As a general rule, a mixture of fact and fiction seems to envelop the history of the organization as well as its grim origins.

In the modern age, the Apostles of the Gospel remain active throughout Kyrmoria. There is no clear hierarchy, according to their ancient edict, and members aren't forced to reveal anything more than what is revealed to them. Thusly, there exists no formal base of operation, and members of the faction oftent act independently according to their own wishes and desires. No loyalty is required among members and, besides three rules called "The Whispering Triad", foul play between colleagues is all but uncommon. A volatile environment engulfed in chaos and conspiracy, constituting an enticing opportunity for those accustomed to such living, many members of the organization are trained in the ways of the rogue or the blackguard, as well as practice the arcane through wizardry or manipulation of the Song of Origin, like bards.

The apostles' dogma is centered on the delusional belief of the world coming to a rebirth, which is viewed upon as their sacred duty to herald. As such, there is ever if any who would welcome a known apostle into any peaceful meet, despite the ironic fact that many within the organization possess extensive knowledge of vast and forgotten secrets, due to their ancient beginnings. Followers of the dogma are welcomed into the apostles with but a simple offering of their conviction, usually in the form of some ruinous secret, be it their own, or someone's who stands in opposition of the dogma (usually a known preacher or scholar of fate). Of course, greater gifts such as a stolen relic of arcane or divine nature, or even the indictment of other members are viewed upon with impressed appreciation.
Any who join the apostles are only ever expected to adhere to "The Whispering Triad", presented below:

items: {@i "You shall always seek for the holy texts of the one true god, frivolously and without stop. Any who recover them must bear them all their lives, till glorious rebirth sunders all."}
{@i "You shall always thwart those promising renewal and continuity, for their lies are a sacrilege to the inevitable end."}
{@i "You shall only act to terminate or enlighten those of knowledge enough to the gospel's truth."}

entries.name: Goals
entries: "The Inevitable Rebirth", or "The Inevitable End" as is called in the dark gospel the apostles follow, is the final goal of their efforts. While most of the members of the faction possess aspirations that frequently conflict between even the more prominent members of their sect, resulting usually in the abhorrent end of one or both, any believer of the dogma follows the fruitless search for the completion of their dark god's ultimate dream.

While no official hierarchy exists, making the apostles nigh impervious to scrutiny under any means, a byproduct of their original creation, not all members are equal. The apostles are, in great irony, almost a perfect aristocracy, as those of greater power, in knowledge or ability, are usually the ones followed more frequently in whatever plots they concoct, many times by those vying for their untimely death, ready to push on the advantage. Thus, while no benefit or influence stems from the titling, many, in part newer apostles, come to bestow senior members with titles often presented in theocratic societies.

While no rules exist within the faction, regarding the number of currently titled members, circumstance or plot seems to constantly enforce a steadiness to the rankings. The only who is rumored among members to hold any significant value is of the Cardinal, a post presented in some ancient lore as the scribe of their dark god, imbued with not only his direct influence but with the sacred responsibility of calling the gathering of the pages, on the most sanctified of days, once every winter's solstice, to inspect the authenticity of the gathered texts and congratulate the secret holders, accompanied usually by a myriad of apostle corpses at the breaking of dawn, when new holders are promptly blessed.

entries.name: Relationships
entries: The Apostles of the Gospel have no real ties with any other organization in Kyrmoria. Hated by mostly anyone who knows of their existence and rarely if ever tolerated, the apostles ignore the goals of almost anyone other than themselves. While sometimes, under guise of other, an apostle may travel within a party, it is an inevitable fate that in the future to come, his true character will be promptly revealed to be capricious, cruel, and oftentimes insane. Apostles are rarely known to employ mercenaries, mostly those proficient at tracking and killing without notice, as is the usual route taken regarding those poor few who come to acknowledge their existence and show no interest in achieving their enlightened spirit.

One exception to the aforementioned concerns the followers of the Fate Weaver. Eons ago, during the imprisonment of the master that the apostles feverishly seek to release, it was she, that pointed out his ambition and coaxed the other divines into action. Therefore, almost any apostle will seek to defile, destroy and corrupt any follower or religious site of the Fate Weaver, as long as the act does not intervene with their original cause.

entries.name: Figures of Interest
entries: These figures are major members of the Apostles of the Gospel that you can use as NPCs in your game. You could also take inspiration from these figures to make up new NPCs for your own campaign.

entries.name: Deacon of Whispers, Velkath Barzig
entries: {@i Human scholar, neutral evil}

Velkath is a young man in his mid twenties. He joined the apostles at the tender age of fourteen, following in his father's footsteps, by performing a ritual of self scaring in front of a small gathering among the crypt elders, peers and hated rivals of his family.

Tall and lanky, with short black hair and blue eyes, he travels the world noticed by some, who he promptly tries to sway to his preaching with unparallel zeal. More often than not, he leaves behind a maimed body rather than an enlightened child.

Recently his ambition has grown, to the point where his role as deacon has become stale for his tastes. Velkath is plotting for the disappearance of one of the crypt elders, looking for a moment of opportunity with constant anticipation.

entries.name: Crypt Elder, Vorgause Barzig
entries: {@i Human wizard (necromancer), chaotic evil}

The firstborn child of the House of Barzig, a family well established and prodigious when it comes to commerce in the Republic, Vorgause enjoyed every luxury in his early years. He was given the greatest of educations and, in his early twenties, earned a scholarship for a prestigious mage academy.

Clever, sociable and charming was what many would describe him as, except for those unlucky enough to come face to face with his unyielding curiosity for the nature of death. Vorgause's fascination started as an "itch" when he was young, many victims needrd to satisfy it, the cover of his background and quick wits assisting him in remaining undetected.

When he studied the arcane, he grew fascinsted, as was natural, with the necromantic arts. One of his professors noticed and offered him great insight into the occult practices, eventually revealing to Vorgause his identity as an apostle and urging him to join.

Vorgause has since rised in ranks both in wizardly academics and in the apostles, utilizing his family's wealth and his cunning to perfect his craft and attain information about the whereabouts of magical items of interest, often visiting the black market of Dhen Razheem under disguise.

entries.name: Bishop of Rebirth, Anasteria Felix
entries: {@i Elf vampire cleric (ur-priest), lawful evil}

Anasteria was a talented priestess of Lymira before experiencing her first death. When was sent to the first joint expendition looking to unearth old artifacts from the Second Age in the Shifting Barrens, her team ventured into a long lost crypt beneath the sands and, unfortunately, met an agent of the Forgotten Prince, who single handedly slayed them all.

Anasteria didn't receive the mercy of a permanent demise and, perhaps on a whim of the agent's patron, found herself awake amongst the corpses of her peers, a thirst for mortal blood burning deep inside her. Cursing her fate and her goddess for not answering her pleas, yet lacking the resolve of ending her own unlife, she spent many decades unfolding the secrets of her profane maker.

Anasteria eventually found solace only in thoughts of vengeance, and joined the Apostles in secret hopes of acquiring a secret from the gospel powerful enough to undo the one who doomed her to her fate.

entries.name: Cardinal of the Gospel, Veremir Merinthor
entries: {@i Hellfire lich (blackgurd/warlock), neutral evil}

Little is left in the history texts of the former king of Merinthor, aside from tales of his greatness and untimely demise at the hands of his second son. What no text or living memory holds, however, is the fact that Veremir orchestrated his own death.
After secretly plotting for three aeons, Veremir has now acquired unspeakable powers and is spearheading the Apostles across Kyrmoria and beyond in their mission of freeing their undying lord.

entries.name: Mythos of the Undying
entries: It is said that once, Xyndaran, the Undying, was the Lorekeeper of the Gods. But he became greedy and jealous, wishing himself able to shape reality instead of recording it, and acting on the matter. When his folly was discovered, his records were taken and he was imprisoned, his duty given to Cyndoriel and Lymira, the second of which ironically was the weaver of fate.

However, it is also said that Xyndaran was sharp, and managed to salvage 1000 pages full of dark secrets that spoke of terrible truths regarding the gods, the mortals, and the whole of creation. He cast 999 of them down in the mortal realm in his final moments, keeping the last and worst one well hidden in the shadowy reaches of his dark domain. The Apostles are said to seek the pages of his Black Gospel, and should their task be complete, Xyndaran will break free from his shackles and with the final page speak the words that will alter the truth of the world.

entries.name: The Cabal
entries: When King Yrvain reclaimed the throne of Merinthor two hundred years ago, many of the higher ranking officers advocating for his brother's right to rule deserted the kingdom, in fear for their lives and the inevitable reforms. Most notable among them, was a group of mages operating under House Xessar, conducting research on mana geodes and Ley Lines. These mages traveled through the Emerald Wilds to avoid pursuit, eventually finding shelter in a ruined city from the Second Age atop the mountain peaks that ascend into Death's Reach. Through clever usage of sorcery, they managed to track the system of caverns lying underground, and chose to hide there. To their surprise, they found an immense amount of mana geodes, ripe for mining, beneath the peaks. Commanding magics that shaped the natural environment inside the caves, they set up a settlement, and through research discovered the strong flow of ley lines close to the location of created mana geodes.

Over time, word traveled among circles of mages and warlocks alike, that beneath the deadly cliffs, a new sanctuary for practitioners of the Art was erected, far from watchful eyes and unrestricted by Kyrmorian law. Nowadays, the citadel of Dhen Razheem stands proud inside the caverns of Death's Reach. Two hundred years of constant research and progress have allured many a mage who wishes to pursue spellcraft through unconventional and cryptic means. The citadel hosts a large market with various treasures of arcane nature, often visited by rogue casters in search of illegal materials or forbidden secrets. Dhen Razheem sports great financial strength, as well as security, due to its natural location. Spearheaded by the Cabal, it is a blossoming haven for mercenaries and criminals looking for work or evading judgment. However, the Cabal rules absolute, enforcing their own, unchallenged authority, with an iron fist.

Recently, the Cabal have doubled their efforts in mining mana geodes, as well as in fortifying Dhen Razheem. Rumours have it that some sort of large scale operation is at hand, or that perhaps there has been an imporant breakthrough in their endeavors to uncover lost arcana.

items: {@i "Power is law, and knowledge is power. It comes only to those who would do anything to achieve it."}
{@i "Trust in the Art, and pursue its elevation at all costs. All things have a beginning, and so does magic."}
{@i "Truth is the tale of the survivors. The rest, is history."}

entries.name: Goals
entries: The Cabal are a crafty lot, evident by the fact that they have managed to not only shelter Dhen Razheem from Kyrmoria, but also due to their advanced research on magecraft and particularly the mining and refining of mana geodes. Cabal members are expected to act in favor of the organization, promoting the status of their faction through business deals with outsiders.

The Cabal lead Kyrmoria in terms of mana geode extraction and trade, a fact they constantly abuse to further their wealth and influence, even having some of their own installed as shadow member in governmental positions. The Cabal also sanction a vast network of slave trading, normally forbidden through the Accords.

Furthermore, all members of the organization are mages, and so they are expected to do all in their power to advance the Art, especially through innovative usage of mana geodes. Some of their higher ranking members are esteemed and well known as excellent mages throughout the land, even though their ethics are questionable, at best.

As is natural, a haven for outlaws has its fair share of illegar trade nad smuggling, and this is something the Cabal take great advantage of. Dhen Razheem's black market is filled with magical wonders of days past, unearthed through various expenditions or stolen from collectors and safekeepers. If one seeks forbidden or relinquished knowledge, the Cabal and their associates are certainly a promising solution, albeit at great costs.

Up until the rank of Inner, a member of the Cabal enjoys various luxuries, but isn't allowed entry to the secret sanctums and laboratories the faction possesses. However, that changes once they reach said rank, and are relieved of more practical duties, having proven their worth, to focus on research, experiments and leadership. In addition, members of the Inner rank and above wear silver masks while in public, as a means to protect their identity, and are usually accompanied by some sort of personal guard, most often including arcane constructs. High Invokers handle all affairs concerning diplomacy and book-keeping, while the three golden-masked members of the Triumvrate, each reverently refered to as Ipsissimus, expertly manipulate the threads that bind the Cabal in its mystical quest.

entries.name: Relationships
entries: The Cabal have many trade contracts with the Sunlords of the Shifting Barrens and some wealthy individuals in the Kyrmoria Republic, maintaining a friendly business relationship with them. Furthermore, some Apostles of the Gospel visit the market of Dhen Rahzeem frequently to trade secrets for information, and have some form of tenuous alliance with member of the Cabal.

Members of the Shadowblades, an elite assassin's guild from the Kyrmoria Republic also partake in the wonders traded through Dhen Razheem, or fulfill highly prestigious contracts commission by the Cabal. The Acolytes of the Veil, another organization that concerns itself with magical and historical lore, view the Cabal as a dangerous lot, but do hold their efforts to further the Art in some esteem, regardless of the inevitable conflict that occures between the two factions on the occasional expendition with a common destination.

The city-state of Bastion and the Cabal share interest in the trade of mana geodes, and that has driven the two apart, with growing tensions and a lack of diplomatic relations between them. This discord is also present between the Cabal and the kingdom of Merinthor, as is natural, due to the organization's origins. The Fey Enclave does not hold disdain for the Cabal, but due to their own conflict with the flying cities of the Shifting Barrens, which benefit from trading with Dhen Razheem, they have banned all Cabal caravans and operatives from activity in their territory. The greatest adversaries of the Cabal, however, are those of the Scarlet Coven, who view the Cabal's machinations, especially slave trade, as an insult to all of their beliefs. Unbeknownst to the rest of the world, there is also a feud between the Mortal Sages and this group of secretive mages, due to reasons that have never left the tightly sealed lips of both factions.

entries.name: Figures of Interest
entries: These figures are major members of the Cabal that you can use as NPCs in your game. You could also take inspiration from these figures to make up new NPCs for your own campaign.

entries.name: Initiate, Dorafir Ashenbark
entries: {@i High elf alchemist, chaotic evil}

Dorafir is a wanted criminal from the Fey Enclave, after found practicing his alchemy on living beings in quite unethical ways. He managed to escape justice and sought refuge in the Cabal. Now serving the Triumvrate in Dhen Razheem, he uses his alchemical skills to further their goals. Dorafir is a master of potion-making and specializes in potions that can enhance one's magical abilities.
Currently, he is researching a special concoction imbued with fragments of mana geodes, which upon consumption can prove quite potent and addictive.

entries.name: Triumvrate Ipsissimus, Baltazhar Xessar
entries: {@i Human wizard (universalist), chaotic evil}

House Xessar is one of the three noble houses of Merinthor, yet Baltazhar holds no love for his ancestral home. After he graduated from the Academy of War, he grew disillusioned with the politics of the Kingdom and left to join the Cabal, brining great shame to his house and a hefty bounty to his name.

Baltazhar utilized his talent for magecraft as well as the facilities of the Cabal to scheme his way into becoming one of the three leaders, after orchestrating the death of his predecessor. He now spearheads a special operation in Dhen Razheem, the purpose of which is creating an artifical Crest that will allow him to harness the power of a Nexus.

Baltazhar is a cunning mage who will stop at nothing to get what he wants. He is highly ambitious, and has a deep-seated hatred for anyone who stands in his way. He is not above using any means necessary to achieve his goals.

entries.name: Triumvrate Ipsissimus, Krissetra Duskblossom
entries: {@i Dark elf sorcerer (claret soul), neutral evil}

Krissetra Duskblossom is a powerful sorceress and one of the three leaders of the Cabal. Having been taken from her family at a young age and experimented upon by a group of rogue arcane researchers, she developed magical powers, and especially an affinity for hemomancy.

After being rescued, she was taken in by the Cabal, and has been a part of the organization since, rising up to her current position of power through her powerful magic and her cunning mind. She excells in manipulation and deception, using her magic and wits to get what she wants, which is still a mystery even among her peers.

Krissetra is a woman of few words, and even fewer emotions. She is calculating and clinical, rarely ever giving into passion or impulse. Leading through fear, she instills terror and respect in her followers, especially when wielding her powerful blood magic.

spell.name: Arcane Blast
entries: You gather magical energy within yourself and unleash it in a powerful blast. All creatures within 20 feet of you must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes {@damage 7d6} force damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one, and every creature that fails the save is pushed 10 feet away from you and knocked {@condition prone}.
In addition, unsecured objects within the area of the blast take {@damage 7d6} force damage and are likewise pushed 10 feet away from you.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the damage increases by {@scaledice 7d6|4-9|1d6} and the distance pushed increases by 5 feet for each slot level above 4th.

spell.name: Arcane Bolt
entries: You extend your hand, sending a bolt of pure force at a creature or object within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 2d4} force damage.
This spell's damage increases by {@damage 2d4} when you reach 5th level ({@damage 4d4}), 11th level ({@damage 6d4}), and 17th level ({@damage 8d4}).

spell.name: Arcane Lance
entries: You condense raw magic in your hand and hurl it in the form of a lance at a creature you can see within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 6d6} force damage.

The lance travels in a straight 5-foot wide line between you and the target. Each creature excluding you and the target within 5 feet of the line as the lance travels must make a Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 6d6} force damage on a failed save, and half as much damage on a successful one.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Blade Mirage

m.text: a melee weapon you are proficient with worth at least 1 sp

entries: You touch the weapon used in the spell's casting and imbue it with illusory magic. When you cast the spell and as a bonus action on subsequent turns until the spell ends, you can cause illusory copies of the weapon to assault a creature of your choice you can see, forcing it to make an Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, you gain advantage on the next attack you make with the weapon against the target before the end of the current turn.

As an action, a creature that can see you can make an Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check against your spell save DC. If it succeeds, you can no longer gain advantage on attacks with the weapon against that creature with this spell for the duration.

Creatures that are {@condition blinded||blind}, don't rely on sight to perceive their surroundings, such as with {@sense blindsight}, or can see through illusions, such as with {@sense truesight}, are immune to the effects of this spell.

spell.name: Cardoso's Memory Palace
entries: You allow one creature to delve into the depths of its own memory, guiding them through the process. When you finish casting the spell, you touch a willing creature and both your and the target's consciousnesses are thrust into its memories until the spell ends, your physical bodies remaining in the same position as when you finished casting the spell.

While in the target's memories, the target has access to any memory it has gained in its existence, even those removed by unnatural means such as modify memory or due to physical, or mental trauma. The target can choose to access and relive any of its memories in perfect accuracy from a first person view, including emotions, thoughts and actions. The target, however, can't alter any of its memories in any sort of way, and once it begins experiencing a memory, it will keep experiencing it until it ends. You see any memory the target experiences as well, but from a third person view as if witnessing it from above, and you are also unable to alter or interact with the target's memories in any sort of way.

Experiencing memories takes place in the same time span as the actual memory. For example, if the target experiences a one hour dinner during this spell, one hour passes in the physical world as well. Therefore, the total amount of time in memories that the target can experience is equal to the duration of this spell, and if the spell ends while the target is still experiencing a memory, that memory is cut short.

Similarly, while not experiencing a memory, yours and the target's consciousnesses exist in a blank space within the target's mind, and can converse normally, with time passing in the blank space at the same rate as in the physical world.

This spell puts immense mental stress on the target. After each experienced memory, the target must make an Intelligence saving throw with a DC of 5 + an additional 2 for each experienced memory beyond the first. On a failed save, the target completely loses any recollection of one important part of the memory they experienced when they made the saving throw (GM's discretion).

When the spell ends, or immediately when you or the target's physical bodies take damage or are physically harmed in any way, both your and the target's consciousnesses return to your physical bodies, and both you and the target gain 1 point of {@condition exhaustion}.

spell.name: Dimensional Anchor
entries: Green-tinted energy encircles your hand and streaks towards a creature of your choice within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target becomes unable to move or be moved using teleportation or by extradimensional or interplanar means until the spell ends. This also prevents the target from passing or being pulled through an interdimensional portal, such as the one made by {@spell teleportation circle}.

At the end of each of the target's turns, it can make a Charisma saving throw against the spell. On a success, the spell ends. If the target of the spell is a summoned creature, the summoned creature is not prevented from disappearing at the appropriate time, such as when the spell that summoned it ends.

spell.name: Dimensional Slash

m.text: a melee weapon you are proficient with worth at least 1 sp

entries: You brandish the weapon used in the spell's casting and unleash a slash, cutting through dimensions. Each creature in a 15-foot cone must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes force damage equal to the damage dice of the weapon used in the spell's casting plus an additional {@damage 4d6} force damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
This spell also affects creatures in the ethereal plane.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 3rd.

spell.name: Disjunction
entries: You unleash devastating abjuration magic in an area with a 30-foot radius centered on you, disrupting the weave of magic itself. Spells and other magical effects not originating from you in the affected area are immediately dispelled as if targeted by a dispel magic spell cast with a spell slot of 9th level, regardless of their possible immunity to being dispelled by dispel magic, such as the one of wall of force. All magic items with a rarity of legendary or lower in the affected area must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or lose all their properties and become nonmagical permanently. Magic items have a bonus on this saving throw in addition to their possible Wisdom saving throw bonus if they are sentient, depending on their rarity, as follows:
A magic item in possession of a creature has a bonus to this saving throw equal to the Wisdom saving throw bonus of the creature wielding it.
If this spell is cast within an area affected by an {@spell antimagic field}, make an ability check using your spellcasting ability.

The DC is equal to the spell save DC of the creature that cast the {@spell antimagic field}. On a successful check, the {@spell antimagic field} ends. On a failed check, this spell ends and has no effect.

Finally, this spell has the potency to disjunct even magic items of the highest power, albeit at a cost. A magic item with a rarity of artifact or higher that is in the area affected by this spell has advantage as well as a +5 bonus on the saving throw to resist its effects. If such an item fails its saving throw to resist the effects of this spell, roll a {@dice d100}. On a 5 or higher on the roll, you attract the attention of some powerful being who has interest or a connection with the item (GM's choice).

spell.name: Elbalar's Temporal Slash
entries: You wave your hand, opening a tear in time in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that cone must make a Wisdom saving throw or vanish until the spell ends, as you attempt to temporarily remove them from the current timeline. When the spell ends, affected creatures reappear where they were or in the closest unoccupied space. Affected creatures don't remember you casting the spell or being affected by it.

spell.name: Elemental Mage Armor

components.m: adamantine ore and {@footnote {@note something}|The source simply writes "adamantine ore and".}

entries: You touch a willing creature who isn't wearing armor, and a protective magical force surrounds it until the spell ends. The target's base AC becomes 15 + its Dexterity modifier. The spell ends if the target dons armor or if you dismiss the spell as an action.
In addition, while benefiting from this spell, the target has resistance to one of the following damage types of your choice: acid, cold, fire, lightning or thunder.

spell.name: Emergency Transposition

time.condition: which you take when a creature that you can can see targets you with an attack

entries: You attempt to evade an incoming attack by teleporting yourself out of harm's way, swapping places with another creature, except the creature that targeted you with the triggering attack.

Choose a space within range that is occupied by a Small or Medium creature that you can see. If that creature is willing, you both teleport, swapping places, and the creature becomes the new target of the attack. If that creature is unwilling, it must make a Charisma saving throw. On a successful save, the spell fails and has no effect. On a failed save, you both teleport, swapping places, and the creature becomes the new target of the attack.

spell.name: False Sending

components.m: A short piece of corroded copper wire

entries: You send a short message of twenty-five words or less to a creature with which you are familiar. When you do so, you may choose to impersonate another creature that both you and the recipient of the message are familiar with and try to make it appear so that the sender of the message was the impersonated creature.

The recipient of the message hears the message in its mind, and must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the recipient of the message is convinced that the sender is the impersonated creature. On a successful save, the recipient of the message understands the nature of the impersonation and knows that the impersonated creature and the sender are not the same person, but can't discern your real identity even if it knows you. The creature receiving the message can answer in a like manner immediately. The spell enables creatures with Intelligence scores of at least 1 to understand the meaning of your message.
You can send the message across any distance and even to other planes of existence, but if the target is on a different plane than you, there is a {@chance 5} chance that the message doesn't arrive.

spell.name: Greater Mage Armor

m.text: adamantine ore and a ruby worth at least 300 gp, which the spell consumes

entries: You touch a willing creature who isn't wearing armor, and a protective magical force surrounds it until the spell ends. The target's base AC becomes 15 + its Dexterity modifier. The spell ends if the target dons armor or if you dismiss the spell as an action.
In addition, while benefiting from this spell, the target has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks.

spell.name: Magic Vestment
entries: You touch a suit of nonmagical armor or a nonmagical {@item shield|PHB}. Until the spell ends, the item you touched gains the following properties depending on its type:

entries.name: Suit of Armor
entries: The suit of armor becomes magical and any creature wearing it has a +1 bonus to AC.

entries.name: Shield
entries: The {@item shield|PHB} becomes magical and any creature holding it has a +1 bonus to AC, in addition to the shield's normal bonus to AC.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, the bonus increases to +2. When you use a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the bonus increases to +3.

spell.name: Mystic Blade Charge

m.text: a melee weapon you are proficient with worth at least 1 sp

entries: You brandish the weapon used in the spell's casting and transform into a torrent of ethereal arcane energy. Choose a creature you can see within range. You teleport to an unoccupied space of your choice you can see within 5 feet of the target.

When you finish teleporting, you can make a weapon attack with the weapon used in the spell's casting against the target. On a hit, the target suffers the weapon attack's normal effects and takes an additional {@damage 2d6} force damage.

Additionally, immediately after you finish teleporting, the path in a 5-foot-wide line between the space you left and the space you appear in is ravaged by arcane energy. Any creature within 5 feet of the line, excluding you and the target, must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes force damage equal to the damage dice of the weapon plus your spellcasting ability modifier.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the range of the spell increases by 30 feet, and the damage increases by {@dice 1d6} for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Retaliating Counter

time.condition: which you take when a creature that you can see within the spell's range deals damage to you

m.text: a melee weapon you are proficient with worth at least 1 sp

entries: You brandish the weapon used in the spell's casting and vanish to perform a retaliating strike. You teleport to an unoccupied space you can see within 5 feet of the creature that dealt damage to you and can immediately make a weapon attack against it with the weapon used in the spell's casting.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the range of the spell increases by 30 feet for each slot level above 2nd, and on a hit, the weapon attack you make as part of casting this spell deals an extra {@damage 1d8} force damage for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Scholarly Touch
entries: You touch one nonmagical object covered in writing, such as a book or a scroll, and absorb the knowledge contained within it as if you had just read it. The knowledge you acquire is equal to a thorough reading, but not deep study. Therefore, you do not recall all the information contained in the object perfectly, but can give a perfectly good summary of it, and remember important details that you were looking for or found interesting.

Casting this spell again on the same object does not convey any further information, but can refresh your memory on details specified when casting the spell. This spell has no effect if you touch an object covered in writing in a language that you can't read.

spell.name: Undeath to Death

m.text: the powder of a crushed white pearl worth at least 1000 gp

entries: You unleash positive necromantic energy that destroys undead creatures. Roll {@dice 20d10}; the total is how many hit points of undead this spell can affect. Undead within 60 feet of a point you choose within range are affected in ascending order of their current hit points.

Starting with the undead that has the lowest current hit points, each undead affected by this spell is infused with positive necromantic energy that attempts to destroy it completely. Subtract each undead's hit points from the total before moving on to the undead with the next lowest hit points. An undead's hit points must be equal to or less than the remaining total for that undead to be affected.
Undead with resistance or immunity to turn effects can make a Constitution saving throw. On a successful save, they are not affected by this spell.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 8th level or higher, roll an additional {@scaledice 20d10|7-9|10d10} for each slot level above 7th.

spell.name: Vortex Strike

m.text: a melee weapon you are proficient with worth at least 1 sp

entries: You brandish the weapon used in the spell's casting and then vanish to strike through dimensions. Choose up to five creatures you can see within 30 feet of you. Make a melee attack against each target with the weapon used in the spell's casting. On a hit, a target suffers the weapon attack's normal effects and takes an additional {@damage 5d10} force damage.
You can then teleport to an unoccupied space you can see within 5 feet of one of the targets you hit or missed.

spell.name: Warp Strike

m.text: a melee weapon you are proficient with worth at least 1 sp

entries: You brandish the weapon used in the spell's casting and then slash with it, warping space. Choose a creature you can see within 60 feet of you. Make a melee attack against the target with the weapon used in the spell's casting. On a hit, the target suffers the weapon attack's normal effects and takes an additional {@damage 2d6} force damage.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by {@dice 1d6}, and the range increases by 10 feet for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Whirlwind Slash

m.text: a melee weapon you are proficient with worth at least 1 sp

entries: You brandish the weapon used in the spell's casting and perform three powerful slashes in quick succession, sending a razor-sharp torrent of wind towards a creature of your choice you can see within range with each slash. You can direct all slashes towards the same target or towards different targets.
For each slash, make a melee weapon attack with the weapon used in the spell's casting. On a hit, the target of a slash suffers the attack's normal effects and is pushed 10 feet away from you.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, you can perform one additional slash for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Wondrous Projectiles

m.text: a ranged weapon with the ammunition property you are proficient with worth at least 1 sp

entries: You touch and transmute the weapon used in the spell's casting. Until the spell ends, the weapon ignores the loading property if it has it. If you load no ammunition in the weapon, it produces its own, automatically creating one piece of magic ammunition when you make a ranged attack with it, which deals an additional {@damage 2d6} force damage on a hit. The ammunition created by the weapon vanishes the instant after it hits or misses a target, or when the spell ends. If the weapon leaves your possession, the spell ends.

When you make a ranged attack with the weapon using a piece of magic ammunition created by the weapon, you can enchant the piece of ammunition as part of the attack, giving it one of the following effects:

entries.name: Disintegration
entries: A creature hit by the piece of ammunition takes an additional {@damage 4d6} force damage. If this damage reduces a creature to 0 hit points, the target is disintegrated.

entries.name: Displacement
entries: A creature hit by the piece of ammunition must succeed on a Charisma saving throw or be teleported to an unoccupied space you can see within 30 feet of its location.

entries.name: Enthrallment
entries: A creature hit by the piece of ammunition must make a Wisdom saving throw, and it does so with advantage if you or your companions are fighting it. If it fails the saving throw, it is {@condition charmed} by you until the spell ends or until you or your companions do anything harmful to it. The {@condition charmed} creature is friendly to you. When the spell ends, the creature knows it was {@condition charmed} by you.

entries.name: Vacuum
entries: A creature hit by the piece of ammunition and all creatures within 30 feet of it must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, they take {@damage 4d6} thunder damage and are {@condition deafened} until the spell ends. On a successful save, they take half as much damage and are not {@condition deafened}. {@condition Deafened} creatures can repeat this saving throw at the end of each of their turns, ending the effect on themselves on a success.

spell.name: Wraithstrike

m.text: a weapon you are proficient with worth at least 1 sp

entries: You touch and transmute the weapon used in the spell's casting. Until the spell ends, whenever you make a weapon attack using the weapon, if the target is wearing nonmagical armor or no armor at all (even if it has natural armor), you treat its AC as 10 + their Dexterity modifier.
Magical armor as well as magical effects that increase the target's AC can't be bypassed with this spell (such as the {@spell mage armor} and {@spell shield} spells).

item.name: Greater Robe of the Warmage
item.reqAttune: by a sorcerer, warlock or wizard
entries: This elegant, tight-fitted robe is made from exquisite cloth and adorned with runes that pulse with power, imbuing it with arcane wards.
You gain these benefits while wearing the robe:

items: If you aren't wearing armor, you gain a bonus to AC equal to your spellcasting ability modifier.
You have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.
You add your proficiency bonus to any spellcasting ability check you make when casting {@spell counterspell} or {@spell dispel magic}.

The robe has 10 charges. When you cast {@spell counterspell} or {@spell dispel magic}, you can expend charges from the robe in place of your own spell slots, but otherwise cast the spell as normal. For example, you can use 5 charges to cast {@spell counterspell} as a 5th level spell. You can't expend charges this way to cast a spell at a level higher than your highest level spell slot. The robe regains {@dice 1d8 + 2} expended charges daily at dawn.

item.name: Specialist's Focus
entries: This beautiful amulet is elegantly crafted, a mana geode filled with energy secured in its center. The amulet functions as an {@item arcane focus|PHB}.

While wearing this amulet, your spell save DC increases by 2 for spells that you cast that are part of a specific school of magic. The mana geode in the amulet indicates the school of magic, which the GM chooses or determines randomly.

In addition, the amulet has 4 charges and regains {@dice 1d4} charges daily at dawn. When you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher, and it is of a school that matches the gem's type, you can expend any number of charges to increase the level of the spell you cast by the same amount without expending a higher level spell slot.

You can only increase a spell's level this way up to the highest level of spell that you can cast. For example, if you're a 5th-level {@class wizard} and cast a 1st-level spell, you can use 2 charges to cast it as a 3rd-level spell, only expending a 1st-level spell slot in the process. You can't however expend 4 charges to cast it as a 5th-level spell, as you do not already have 5th-level spell slots.

trait.name: Amorphous Form
entries: The spirit can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

trait.name: Antimagic Vulnerability
entries: The spirit is {@condition incapacitated} while in the area of an {@spell antimagic field}. If targeted by {@spell dispel magic}, the spirit must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against the caster's spell save DC or disappear.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The spirit has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The spirit makes a number of force slam attacks equal to half the SL (rounded down).

action.name: Force Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hitYourSpellAttack} to hit, reach 5ft., one target. {@h}{@damage 1d6 + summonSpellLevel} force damage.

action.name: Unleash Wild Magic {@recharge}
entries: The spirit unleashes chaotic arcane energy. Each creature within 10 feet of the spirit must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC, or roll at the {@class sorcerer||sorcerer's} {@table Wild Magic Surge|PHB} table to create a random magical effect.

monster.name: Manaforged Golem

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Antimagic Weakness
entries: While in the area of an {@spell antimagic field}, the golem loses access to all of its traits related to the mana geodes it is imbued with.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Absorption
entries: Whenever the golem is subjected to a damage-dealing spell of 3rd level or lower, and that spell is of a school corresponding to one of the geodes it's imbued with, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the damage dealt.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Mana Geode Enhancement
entries: The golem is imbued with 3 mana geodes that can't be removed from it unless it is {@condition incapacitated}. Each geode corresponds to a different school of magic. Mana geodes are objects with AC 20, 15 hit points and resistance to all damage except force. If a mana geode is reduced to 0 hit points, it is destroyed, and the golem loses its Innate Spellcasting trait associated with that geode's corresponding school of magic. If a mana geode is targeted by {@spell dispel magic}, the golem must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against the caster's spell save DC or lose access to all of its traits related to that specific geode for 1 minute.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The golem makes two melee attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} +8 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) force damage.

action.name: Arcane Pulse {@recharge 5}
entries: Each creature except the golem within 30 feet of the golem must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw, taking 9 ({@dice 2d8}) force damage per active geode the golem is imbued with on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

reaction.name: Negate Spell
entries: The golem targets one creature it can see within 60 feet of it that is casting a spell of a school corresponding to one of the geodes it's imbued with. If the spell is 3rd level or lower, the spell fails, but any spell slots or charges are not wasted.

variant.name: Manaforged Golem Customization
entries: Manaforged golems are constructs customized to the needs of their creators and masters, most notably the higher ranking members of Dhen Razheem's Cabal. Due to the implementation of mana geodes in their making, the golems possess magical abilities beyond what one might expect, even including access to some spellcasting. Normally, a manaforged golem is imbued with three geodes, but some of the personal golems belonging to the leaders of the Cabal are further modified. Furthermore, most manaforged golems have one extra features defining them apart from the spellcasting granted by mana geodes, unless they serve one of the Cabal's leaders.

entries.name: Innate Spellcasting
entries: The golem's spellcasting ability is Constitution (spell save {@dc 15}). Depending on the school of magic associated with each mana geode a manaforged golem is imbued with, it gains access to certain spells of 1st through 3rd level, each of which it can cast 3 times per day, requiring no material components. If the golem takes the {@b {@i Multiattack}} action, it can forgo one of its attacks to cast one of these spells with a casting time of 1 action in its place. Below are presented the most common choices, though it is not unheard of to make slight modifications on a golem that serves a specific purpose:

items.name: Divination Geode Innate Spellcasting.
items.entry: {@spell detect magic}, {@spell locate object}, {@spell see invisibility}

items.name: Enchantment Geode Innate Spellcasting.
items.entry: {@spell hold person}, {@spell sleep}, {@spell zone of truth}

entries.name: Master's Bond
entries: The golem's creator can communicate with it telepathically while both are within 1 mile of each other. As an action, the creator can see through the golem's eyes and hear what it hears until the start of the creator's next turn, gaining the benefits of any special senses the golem has. During this time, the creator is {@condition deafened} and {@condition blinded} with regard to its own senses.

entries.name: System Shock
entries: If the golem hits a target with two or more slam attacks on its turn, it can use its bonus action to draw on the energy from one of its geodes and channel it through the target. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. If the golem uses this bonus action, it loses access to all of its traits related to the specific geode it drew power from until the start of its next turn.

The Cabal of Dhen Razheem have long experimented with various ways of utilizing mana geodes as weapons of magical nature. Their most recent success is incorporating these geodes into golems, allowing the golem access to various abilities depending on the strain of the geodes. These new creations serve as bodyguards for members of the Cabal holding a significant rank within the organization, but rumors exist of secret deals with the leaders among the flying cities of the Shifting Barrens, concerning mass production of these constructs.

entries.name: Obedience
entries: Manaforged golems operate under the commands of the Cabal, executing all assigned tasks to perfection. Due to their symbiosis with mana geodes, their creators can use the weave of magic to mentally perceive the golem's surroundings should a particular golem be tinkered with for this type of function. These golems are excellent combatants, harnessing the innate magic of the mana geodes to incapacitate intruders or enemies of their masters.

entries.name: Manaforged Nature
entries: A manaforged golem doesn't require air, food, drink or sleep.

entries.name: Tactics - Manaforged Golem
entries: The following tactics represent the standard order of operations a manaforged golem takes, such as the one presented in the statblock provided in the previous page. A manaforged golem typically likes to open combat with {@b {@i Arcane Pulse}}, if it can affect two or more enemies, before entering melee. If it is unable to, it will enter melee and take the {@b {@i Multiattack}} action, possibly replacing one of its attacks with a spell it has access to through {@b {@i Innate Spellcasting}}, if the situation is appropriate. A manaforged golem will always attempt to stay within 60 feet of any spellcasters it perceives, in an effort to possibly thwart their spells with its {@b {@i Negate Spell}} reaction, and it will attempt to use its {@b {@i Arcane Pulse}} whenever it is available if it can affect two or more enemies, and two or more of the mana geodes it is imbued with are still active. If a manaforged golem is fighting alongside its master, it uses everything in its arsenal to protect or secure retreat for them.

entries.name: Prior to Combat
entries: If the manaforged golem acknowledges that it is going to enter combat, but has time to prepare, it casts any available spell to it through its {@b {@i Innate Spellcasting}} trait to buff itself, or debuff multiple enemies.

entries.name: Round 1.
entries: The manaforged golem moves towards any creature it can perceive as being easier to hit, and takes the {@b {@i Multiattack}} action. If both of its attacks hit the same target and it has the {@b {@i System Shock}} trait, it uses it as a bonus action.

entries.name: Round 2
entries: The manaforged golem uses its {@b {@i Arcane Pulse}}. action if available. If not, due to its brutish nature, namely the fact that it must fight in the melee, it takes the {@b {@i Multiattack}} action, targeting any creature it can reach without suffering {@action opportunity attack||opportunity attacks}, and possibly using its {@b {@i System Shock}} as a bonus action.

entries.name: Round 3
entries: The manaforged golem takes the {@b {@i Multiattack}} action, targeting any spellcasters it can perceive, or the most injured target it can reach.

entries.name: Round 4
entries: If the manaforged golem has sustained considerable damage, it will take the {@action Dodge} action, and attempt to flee and send a signal to its master, should it be fighting by itself. Alternatively, it uses its {@b {@i Arcane Pulse}} or {@b {@i Multiattack}} action, attempting to inflict as much damage as possible, until its master arrives.

entries.name: Round 5
entries: The manaforged golem repeats its actions from {@b {@i Round 1}} onwards, or attempts to escape combat if it has the option to.

variantrule.name: Class Kits
entries: Not all members of a class are alike, and they differ in more than simply their subclasses. Some {@class cleric||clerics} have an inner affinity with negative energy, instead of positive energy, while some {@class paladin||paladins} never swear an oath and instead follow the path of wickedness.

entries.name: Class Kit Rules
entries: In the following section, we present the rules regarding class kits, should you wish to incorporate them in your games.

entries.name: When to Take a Class Kit
entries: Consulting with your DM, you decide whether to take a class kit when creating your character. Alternatively, when you gain your 1st level in a class (such as with multiclassing) or reach a level in your class that grants the Ability Score Improvement feature, you can take a class kit, replacing your class's features with the corresponding features of the class kit, at your GM's discretion.

entries.name: What's a Class Kit
entries: Class kits are "packages" of optional class features. If you take a class kit, all of that class kit's features replace or modify the class features you normally gain from your class at the character levels noted in the class kit's description, unless explicitly noted otherwise. For example, when you make a {@class cleric} character, if your GM allows you to take the necrolord class kit, you replace the {@class cleric||cleric's} {@classFeature Channel Divinity: Turn Undead|Cleric||2||Turn Undead} with the necrolord class kit's Rebuke Undead when you reach 2nd level in the {@class cleric} class. If a feature from a class kit you take replaces another feature, you gain no benefit from the replaced one and don't qualify for anything in the game that requires it.

entries.name: Features and Qualifications
entries: When you take a class kit, you only replace some specific features from your class. You are still considered a member of your class for anything in the game that requires you to have a level in your class, such as attuning to a specific item. You also gain the same class features as your class, except from those replaced by the features of the class kit you take.

For example, if you're a 10th-level necrolord (with the necrolord {@class cleric} class kit), you are also considered a 10th-level {@class cleric} for anything in the game that requires it, such as the {@classFeature Divine Intervention|Cleric||10} {@class cleric} class feature. Some class kits might break this rule, due to extreme dichotomies between the class kit's theme and the original class. One such example is the blackguard class kit, which is a class kit of the {@class paladin} class, and such exceptions will always be explicitly noted.

entries.name: Multiple Class Kits
entries: You can take multiple class kits. You still need your GM's permission and the same rules apply, but you can be a necrolord ur-priest, for example. However, there is a restriction to that: You can't take two class kits that replace or modify the same feature, or take a class kit that replaces or modifies a feature that's already replaced or modified by another class kit you've taken.

If you take two or more class kits, and one of them states that you do not qualify as a member of your class for anything in the game that requires it, that statement supersedes any other class kit that might still allow you to qualify as a member of your class for anything in the game that requires it.

For example, if you take both the {@optfeature mystic knight|CoH-CAPG} and blackguard class kits when you make your {@class paladin} character, you do not qualify as a member of the {@class paladin} class for anything in the game that requires it, since the blackguard class kit supersedes the {@optfeature mystic knight|CoH-CAPG} class kit in this manner.

entries.name: Subclasses and Class Kits
entries: Some class kits offer a feature that replaces the feature that would normally grant your character access to a subclass. One such example is the ur-priest's 1st-level feature, Shun the Gods, which replaces the 1st-level {@classFeature Divine Domain|Cleric||1} feature of the {@class cleric} class. In such cases, the new feature will grant you benefits at the levels where you would normally gain subclass features. Consider these types of class kits as "subclasses" that modify your entire class.

optionalfeature.name: Curse of Bleeding
entries: At the start of each of its turns while its current hit points are below its hit point maximum, the target must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, its current hit points are reduced by an amount equal to {@dice 1d4} + your Charisma modifier and it can't regain hit points until the start of its next turn.

entries.name: Empowered
entries: When you empower this curse, the hit point reduction increases by {@scaledice 2d4|1-4|1d4} per level of the spell slot.

optionalfeature.name: Curse of Fatigue
entries: When you curse the target and at the start of each of the target's turns, the target must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save it suffers the effects of one level of {@condition exhaustion} until the start of its next turn.

entries.name: Empowered
entries: When you empower this curse, the target suffers the effects of one additional level of {@condition exhaustion} for a 3rd or 4th-level spell slot, and the effects of two additional levels of {@condition exhaustion} for a 5th-level or higher spell slot.

optionalfeature.name: Curse of Feebleness
entries: When you curse the target and at the start of each of the target's turns, the target must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it takes a −1 penalty to all attack and damage rolls it makes until the start of its next turn.

entries.name: Empowered
entries: When you empower this curse, the penalty to attack and damage rolls increases by 1 per level of the spell slot.

optionalfeature.name: Curse of Fury
entries: At the start of each of the target's turn, it must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it must use its reaction to make a melee attack against the closest creature it can reach, using its movement to reach it if it has to (as part of this reaction). If two or more creatures have the same distance from the cursed target, the GM determines which creature is attacked, randomly.

entries.name: Empowered
entries: When you empower this curse, the attack the target is forced to make when it fails its saving throw deals an extra {@scaledamage 1d6|1-4|1d6} necrotic damage per level of the spell slot on a hit.

optionalfeature.name: Curse of Infatuation
entries: When you curse the target, it must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a successful save, the curse fails to affect the target. On a failed save, the target is {@condition charmed} by you while the curse lasts or until you or your companions do anything harmful to it. The {@condition charmed} creature regards you as a friendly acquaintance and will act to the best of its ability according to its nature in order to please you (GM's discretion).

entries.name: Empowered
entries: When you empower this curse, the curse lasts for 1 hour per level of the spell slot, instead of its normal duration.

optionalfeature.name: Curse of Lethargy
entries: When you curse the target and at the start of each of the target's turns, the target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, its speed is reduced by 10 feet, it takes a −2 penalty to AC and it becomes unable to take reactions until the start of its next turn.

entries.name: Empowered
entries: When you empower this curse, the speed reduction increases by 10 feet per level of the spell slot.

optionalfeature.name: Curse of Lifestealing
entries: The first time on a turn that you deal damage to the target, it takes extra necrotic damage equal to {@damage 1d4} + your Charisma modifier and you gain temporary hit points equal to half the amount of necrotic damage dealt.

entries.name: Empowered
entries: When you empower this curse, the damage increases by {@scaledamage 2d4|1-4|1d4} per level of the spell slot.

optionalfeature.name: Curse of Madness
entries: When you curse the target and the start of each of the target's turns, it must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it must use its action on that turn to cackles, cries or screams maniacally. If it is unable to do so due to not being able to take an action, it becomes {@condition incapacitated} until the start of its next turn.

entries.name: Empowered
entries: When you empower this curse, the target takes {@scaledamage 1d6|1-4|1d6} psychic damage per level of the spell slot each time it fails its saving throw.

optionalfeature.name: Curse of Misfortune
entries: Choose the target's attack rolls, ability checks or saving throws. Whenever the target makes a roll of the chosen type, it must roll a {@dice d4} and subtract the number rolled from the total.

entries.name: Empowered
entries: When you empower this curse, the die the target rolls increases by one size per level of the spell slot, up to a {@dice d12} (for example, if you empower the curse with a 1st-level spell slot, the die's size increases from a {@dice d4} to a {@dice d6}).

optionalfeature.name: Curse of Thorns
entries: Shadowy vines full of thorns engulf the target. When you curse the target, and at the start of each of the target's turns, it must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save it becomes {@condition grappled} by the vines until the start of its next turn.

While {@condition grappled} by the vines, the target can use its action to make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check against your warlock spell save DC. If it succeeds, it takes piercing damage equal to {@damage 1d4} + your Charisma modifier and the grapple ends.

entries.name: Empowered
entries: When you empower this curse, the damage increases by {@scaledamage 2d4|1-4|1d4} per level of the spell slot.

optionalfeature.name: Concealed Names
entries: A new page appears in your Book of Shadows. As an action, provided you permit it, a creature can write its name in the page, which can contain a maximum number of names up to your prodiciency bonus.
Creatures who have written their names in the page are under the effects of a {@spell nondetection} spell as long as their names remain in the page.
As an action, you can touch a name in the page and erase it from it.

optionalfeature.name: Eldritch Scholar
entries: You learn how to scribe magical scrolls. You can transcribe any warlock spell you know or any spell in your Book of Shadows into a scroll, by expending a spell slot with a level equal to or higher the spell's level, as well as 2 hours and 50 gp for each level of the spell, in addition to any material components the spell already has. The level of the spell transcribed into a scroll with this invocation is equal to the level of the spell slot you expended to create the scroll.

Once you have created a scroll with this invocation, it retains its magical potency for a number of days equal to your Charisma modifier (a minimum of one). After this time has passed, the scroll loses its potency and becomes non-magical as the spell is lost.

optionalfeature.name: Tomebound Mastery
entries: Two new pages appear in your Book of Shadows, each containing a cantrip of your choice from any class's spell list (the two needn't be from the same list). While the book is on your person, you can cast those cantrips at will. They count as warlock spells for you, but they don't count against the number of spells you know.

In addition, you can gain any {@filter Eldritch Invocation|optionalfeatures|feature type=EI} that requires the {@spell eldritch blast} cantrip even if you don't know it, and you can apply the effects of that invocation to any cantrip you learn from a feature granted to you by the {@class warlock} class, provided the cantrip requires a ranged spell attack.

optionalfeature.name: Mystic Knight
entries: {@note Qualifies as a {@class paladin}.}

Mystic knights are paladins versed in the ways of the arcane, often mixing it with the divine in pursuit of their cause. Some guard temples dedicated to gods of magic, while others hunt for lost magic troves.

entries.name: Scholar Knight
entries: {@i 1st-level mystic knight feature, which modifies skill proficiencies}
You add the {@skill Arcana} skill to the {@class paladin} class skill list.

entries.name: Sense Magic
entries: {@i 1st-level mystic knight feature, which replaces the {@classFeature Divine Sense|Paladin||1} feature}

As an action, you can open your awareness to detect magical forces. Until the end of your next turn, you know the location of any creature that is able to cast at least one spell within 60 feet of you that is not behind total cover. You also learn each of those creatures' spellcasting abilities, provided they have one. Within the same radius, you also detect the presence of any place or object that has been infused with or that consists of magic, such as a magic item or a ley line.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to 1 + your Charisma modifier. When you finish a long rest, you regain all expended uses.

entries.name: Sense Magic
entries: {@i 2nd-level mystic knight feature}
When you choose a fighting style, the following style is added to your list of options.

entries.name: Mystic Warrior
entries: You learn two {@filter cantrips of your choice from the sorcerer spell list|spells|class=sorcerer|level=0}. They count as {@class paladin} spells for you, and Charisma is your spellcasting ability for them. Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace one of these cantrips with another {@filter cantrip from the sorcerer spell list|spells|class=sorcerer|level=0}.

optionalfeature.name: Psychic
entries: {@note Qualifies as a {@class sorcerer}.}

Psychics are powerful mentalists that manifest their magic thorugh their minds, unlike other sorcerers. A psychic doesn't draw upon innate magical reserves or the power of a bloodline; their power comes from their disciplined mind and their intellect.

entries.name: Psychic's Mind
entries: {@i 1st-level psychic feature}
As a Psychic, you manifest your powers through rigorous mental exercise, shaping the world to your will. The following changes apply to your class features, as detailed below:

items: You gain proficiency with Intelligence saving throws, instead of Charisma saving throws from this class's saving throw proficiencies.
Your spellcasting ability is Intelligence, instead of Charisma.
Any feature you gain from the {@class sorcerer} class that mentions your Charisma modifier, mentions your Intelligence modifier instead, but changes in no other way.

optionalfeature.name: Invoker
entries: {@note Qualifies as a {@class warlock}.}

Invokers are clever mages that earned their spellcasting powers unlike other warlocks. Through their research and fascination with the eldritch, they have formed pacts and wield the gifts of their patrons via the prowess of a calculating mind, instead of a powerful personality.

entries.name: Invoker's Craft
entries: {@i 1st-level invoker feature}

As an Invoker, you utilize the power of your mind to perform the tasks a normal {@class warlock} would simply will into existence. The following changes apply to your class features, as detailed below:

items: You gain proficiency with Intelligence saving throws, instead of Charisma saving throws from this class's saving throw proficiencies.
Your spellcasting ability is Intelligence, instead of Charisma.
Any feature you gain from the {@class warlock} class that mentions your Charisma modifier, mentions your Intelligence modifier instead, but changes in no other way.

subclass.name: Way of the Weave
subclassFeatures: Improved Way of the Weave Technique|Monk||Weave|CoH-CAPG|6
Grandmaster of the Way of the Weave|Monk||Weave|CoH-CAPG|17

colLabels: {@filter Cantrips Known|spells|level=0|subclass=Monk: Way of the Weave (CoH-CAPG)}
{@filter Spells Known|spells|subclass=Monk: Way of the Weave (CoH-CAPG)}

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Mana
entries: Druids that belong to the Circle of Mana have a deep appreciation and understanding of the fact that magic is a living being, indistinguishable from the natural world. These druids harness the power of mana, channeling and giving it form in order to protect the wondrous magical locations in the wild.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of Mana feature}

When you joined this circle, the mana blessed you with knowledge of arcane magic. This blessing grants you access to some spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Circle of Mana table.

Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

entries.caption: Circle of Mana
rows: {@spell mirror image}, {@spell nystul's magic aura||arcanist's magic aura}

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Form
entries: {@i 2nd-level Circle of Mana feature}

You can attune to the lingering mana around you. As a bonus action, you can expend one use of your Wild Shape feature to assume an arcane form, choosing from the options below and gaining the option's benefits as long as you remain in your arcane form, rather than assuming a beast form.

entries.name: Abjuration Form
entries: The mana protects you from harm. You gain a +1 bonus to AC and temporary hit points equal to your druid level + your Wisdom modifier.

entries.name: Conjuration Form
entries: You become one with magic, teleporting swiftly. When you activate this form, and as a bonus action on your subsequent turns while it lasts, you can teleport to an unoccupied space you can see within 10 feet of you.

entries.name: Divination Form
entries: You can read the flow of magic around you. You gain a +1 bonus to saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

entries.name: Enchantment Form
entries: Your physical charm is amplified. You have advantage on Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) and Charisma ({@skill Deception}) checks.

entries.name: Evocation Form
entries: Your spells become more destructive. When you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher that deals damage, you can add your Wisdom modifier to one damage roll of that spell.

entries.name: Illusion Form
entries: The mana takes shape as an illusory duplicate of yourself that shelters you from harm.
